name: Oh No! Yet More Clichés Quiz / Test | Idioms and Proverbs | 10 Questions

questions.text:
Complete this cliché meaning, the common people.

"Every Tom, Dick and ______."
questions.explanation:
Harry.

	This expression is about 200 years old and the names Tom, Dick and Harry were popular at this time. Thus, these names were used to describe the common people or hoi polloi.

questions.text:
If something makes you angry it could be said to -

"make your ______ boil".
questions.explanation:
blood.

	Heat and anger seem to go together, other expressions with a similar theme are "hot and bothered" and "hot under the collar".

questions.text:
When moving from one difficult situation to another the following expression could apply to you.

"From pillar to ______."
questions.explanation:
post.

	This expression is thought to be more than 500 years old. It is probably derived from two forms of public punishment used at that time - the whipping post and the pillory.

questions.text:
What word completes this cliché -

"Hell has no fury like a ______ scorned."?
questions.explanation:
woman.

	"Hell has no fury like a woman scorned" simply means to beware of a woman whose dignity has been affronted.

questions.text:
"Out of sight out of ______."

Which word is missing from this common expression?
questions.explanation:
mind.

	This cliché can be used in two ways. One meaning - you could be overlooked if you do not make your presence felt. It could also mean - stay out of the way and your misdeeds or mistakes might be forgotten.

questions.text:
Complete this cliché which means to make a final attempt or effort -

"He has shot his ______."
questions.explanation:
bolt.

	The bolt in this expression is the special type of arrow used in a crossbow. Once the bolt had been shot it took a while to reload the crossbow. The bowman was then vulnerable to attack whilst he reloaded. He therefore tried to make every shot count.

questions.text: If you were told "to gird your loins", which of these actions would you be expected to perform?
questions.explanation:
prepare for action.

	Girding one's loins is to  belt or fasten loose clothing to free the body for action. This could be in preparation for travelling, working or fighting.

questions.text:
When you are required to explain yourself you could be asked -

"to put your ______ on the table".
questions.explanation:
cards.

	This expression comes from the point of a card game at which a player has to reveal the cards with which he is playing. When you put your cards on the table you reveal your resources or set out your argument.

questions.text:
If you suffer the misfortune of a miserable existence you could be said to be - 

"living a _____ life".
questions.explanation:
dog's.

	The cliché "living a dogs life" was coined some 500 years ago. At that time most dogs lived in poor conditions, feeding on scraps - unlike the much loved and cosseted pets of today.

questions.text:
And finally complete this common expression.

"As sly as a ______."
questions.explanation:
fox.

	The fox has long been admired for its cunning and resourcefulness. This cliché is thought to have been coined some 800 years ago.
